title: RFL could decide to ditch Super 8s system by middle of Super League season
text:
GETTY The Super 8s system has come in for some flack since its introduction 
The RFL are currently consulting all clubs for their views about how the competition should be run in the future. 
This is the third and final year of the trial and it’s looking highly likely that it will be tweaked or possibly abandoned. 
The drama of last season’s Middle 8s relegation battles, and the amazing Million Pound game, created lots of publicity for the sport. 
But there is a growing feeling that it is wrong to glorify the “lesser” teams at the expense of the elite sides.   12. Widnes 
Clubs have also complained about the headaches of organising games for the final seven rounds. 
Those Super 8s fixtures are only known after 23 rounds, which gives clubs little time to drum up publicity or ticket sales. 
Wigan’s Super 8s fixture with St Helens, for example, drew in 14,000 last year when regular derbies attract well over 20,000. 
Teams finishing sixth, seventh or eighth now currently know their seasons are effectively over bar the shouting after 23 rounds. 
But clubs who do worse and finish in the bottom four perversely have more to play for in the Middle 8s, attracting decent crowds into the bargain. 
There are undoubtedly good points to the system and the promotion of Leigh Centurions is proof of that. 
But there are too many other problems, including the timing of the League Leaders Shield, for the system not to be shaken up. Related articles
